questions.text: A 26-year-old female with severe nodulocystic acne has been undergoing treatment with isotretinoin for the past six months. However, she is now planning to start a family and wants to ensure a safe conception. How long should she wait after stopping isotretinoin treatment before attempting to get pregnant to ensure a safe pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C- 1 month: 

Side Effects of Isotretinoin

 

Teratogenicity

Isotretinoin is known to be teratogenic, meaning it can harm the developing fetus during pregnancy. Pregnant women should not use isotretinoin due to the risk of birth defects.

Dryness

Isotretinoin can cause dryness of the skin, leading to increased dryness of the lips, face, and other body parts. Moisturizers can help manage this side effect.

Cheilitis

Cheilitis refers to inflammation and dryness of the lips, commonly seen as chapped or cracked lips, which can occur during isotretinoin treatment.

Ocular Dryness

Isotretinoin may cause dryness of the eyes, leading to discomfort and irritation. Artificial tears can help alleviate ocular dryness.

Headache

Headache is a possible side effect of isotretinoin treatment. If severe or persistent, it should be reported to a healthcare provider.

Secondary Bacterial Colonization

Isotretinoin can lead to increased susceptibility to bacterial infections on the skin, causing secondary bacterial colonization.

Pseudotumor Cerebri

Pseudotumor cerebri is a rare side effect that can cause increased pressure inside the skull. Isotretinoin should not be combined with tetracycline antibiotics, as it can increase the risk of this condition.

Diffuse Interstitial Hyperostosis (DISH)

Diffuse interstitial hyperostosis is a rare but severe side effect characterized by abnormal bone growth along the spine and other skeletal areas.

Depression

Isotretinoin has been associated with mood changes and, in rare cases, can cause or exacerbate depression. Patients should be closely monitored for signs of mood changes during treatment.

Female patients should have a wash-off period of 1 to 3 months between isotretinoin usage and attempting to conceive to reduce the risk of harm to the fetus during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with progressive muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, and slurred speech. He has a family history of a similar condition. Physical examination reveals muscle wasting and weakness. Neurological assessment suggests a peripheral neuropathy. You suspect a sphingolipidosis and consider possible diagnoses.Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is MOST LIKELY associated with this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Sphingolipidosis Enzyme Deficiency Accumulated Sphingolipid Clinical Features
Tay-Sachs Disease Hexosaminidase A GM2 Ganglioside Neurodegeneration, developmental regression, cherry-red spot on the retina, seizures
Sandhoff Disease Hexosaminidase A and B GM2 Ganglioside Similar to Tay-Sachs but more severe and includes visceral involvement
Niemann-Pick Disease Various (e.g., NPC1, NPC2) Sphingomyelin Hepatosplenomegaly, progressive neurodegeneration, cherry-red spot on the retina, foam cells in tissues
Gaucher Disease Glucocerebrosidase Glucocerebroside Hepatosplenomegaly, bone abnormalities, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and fatigue
Fabry Disease Alpha-galactosidase A Globotriaosylceramide Painful neuropathy, skin rashes (angiokeratomas), kidney dysfunction, and cardiac issues
Krabbe Disease Galactocerebrosidase Galactocerebroside Progressive neurodegeneration, peripheral neuropathy, optic nerve atrophy, and developmental delay
Farber Disease Acid ceramidase Ceramide Joint deformities, hoarseness, and painful nodules in subcutaneous tissue
Metachromatic Leukodystrophy Arylsulfatase A Sulfatides Progressive demyelination of the central and peripheral nervous systems, leading to loss of motor and cognitive skills

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is NOT commonly associated with late congenital syphilis in children?

A 28-year-old female with a history of epilepsy is prescribed a new antiepileptic drug (AED) to manage her seizures. She has been previously treated with carbamazepine, which was effective but resulted in troublesome side effects. She is now started on a second-line AED, lamotrigine. After a few weeks on lamotrigine, she presents with a diffuse, erythematous, and maculopapular rash on her trunk, limbs, and face, accompanied by mild fever. Her vital signs are stable, and she reports no other symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this adverse event?

options.label: C
options.text: Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms

questions.correct_answer: C. Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

Drug Rash with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Alternative Name Drug-Induced Hypersensitivity Syndrome (DIHS)
Typical Onset 2-6 weeks after starting the offending medication
Skin Manifestations Diffuse, erythematous, maculopapular rash often involving face, trunk, and limbs
Systemic Symptoms Fever, lymphadenopathy, internal organ involvement (e.g., liver, kidneys, lungs)
Hematological Abnormalities Eosinophilia, atypical lymphocytosis
Laboratory Findings Elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT) and sometimes, renal dysfunction
Common Causative Drugs Various medications, including antiepileptic drugs, sulfonamides, allopurinol, and more
Clinical Complications Hepatitis, nephritis, pneumonitis, myocarditis, and other organ-specific symptoms
Management Immediate withdrawal of the offending medication, supportive care, and sometimes corticosteroids
Prognosis Variable; can be severe, and early recognition and intervention are crucial for a better outcome

questions.text: A 45-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with a persistent, non-resolving cough, fever, and chest pain. A bronchoscopy with biopsy is performed, and the findings are shown in the image below : What is the most likely diagnosis based on the histological findings, and what is the primary clinical concern associated with this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Aspergillosis; risk of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis

options.label: B
options.text: Candidiasis; risk of systemic fungal dissemination

questions.correct_answer: A. Aspergillosis; risk of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Aspergillosis; risk of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis Fungus Microscopic/Histological Appearance Clinical Importance Aspergillus Septate hyphae with acute-angle branching; conidiophores and conidia may be present. Common cause of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in immunocompromised individuals. Candida Yeast forms (budding yeast cells) and pseudohyphae in tissues. Commonly causes candidiasis, which can be mucocutaneous or invasive, especially in immunocompromised patients. Histoplasma capsulatum Small oval-to-round yeast cells within macrophages; granulomatous inflammation may be present. A causative agent of histoplasmosis, primarily affecting the lungs; common in regions with bird or bat droppings. Mucorales (Mucormycosis) Wide, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching; may invade blood vessels. Mucormycosis can cause aggressive tissue necrosis, especially in immunocompromised individuals with diabetic ketoacidosis. Cryptococcus neoformans Encapsulated yeast cells with a halo in India ink preparation; may be intracellular within macrophages. Common cause of cryptococcal infections, including cryptococcal meningitis, often seen in immunocompromised patients. Pneumocystis jirovecii Alveolar spaces filled with cysts containing trophic forms; no true hyphae. Opportunistic pathogen causing Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in immunocompromised individuals, especially in HIV/AIDS.

questions.text: A 47-year-old patient arrives in an unconscious state. Upon clinical examination, the patient's heartbeat is irregular, and there is a discrepancy between the heartbeat and the pulse rate, indicating a pulse deficit. An ECG reveals findings consistent with atrial fibrillation. Following appropriate intervention and stabilization, the patient is discharged with a prescription for the anticoagulant dabigatran to prevent strokes. Which of the following anti-arrhythmic agents is typically utilized in such emergency situations?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

Antiarrhythmic Drug Class

Mechanism of Action

Common Indications

Notable Examples

Class I: Sodium Channel Blockers

Block sodium channels, slowing conduction and reducing excitability of cardiac cells

Ventricular and atrial arrhythmias; used with caution due to proarrhythmic potential

- Procainamide

- Lidocaine

- Flecainide

- Propafenone

Class II: Beta-Blockers

Block beta-adrenergic receptors, reducing sympathetic stimulation of the heart

Supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias; particularly useful in ischemic heart disease

- Metoprolol

- Propranolol

- Esmolol

Class III: Potassium Channel Blockers

Block potassium channels, prolonging action potential duration and refractoriness

Atrial and ventricular arrhythmias; especially effective in atrial fibrillation/flutter

- Amiodarone

- Dofetilide

- Sotalol

Class IV: Calcium Channel Blockers

Block calcium channels, slowing atrioventricular (AV) nodal conduction

Supraventricular arrhythmias; particularly for controlling heart rate in atrial fibrillation/flutter

- Verapamil

- Diltiazem

Miscellaneous (Class V)

Various mechanisms, including adenosine, digoxin, and magnesium

Narrow or wide complex tachycardias; treatment varies based on the drug used

- Adenosine

- Digoxin

- Magnesium sulfate

Others

Variable mechanisms, including newer agents like dronedarone

Specific indications based on mechanism; often used when other classes are contraindicated or ineffective

- Dronedarone

- Ivabradine (for heart rate control)

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has been admitted to the hospital due to a febrile coma that has lasted for the past 2 hours. Prior to admission, he had been experiencing headaches, fever, and chills for several days. Additionally, he exhibited behavioral disturbances and seizures. During the clinical examination, bilateral miosis and a stiff neck were observed. A (CSF) analysis was performed, revealing purulent CSF with pleocytosis (9200 cells/mm3, primarily neutrophils), elevated CSF protein (3.50 g/L), hypoglycorrhachia (1.16 mmol/L; CSF/serum glucose ratio: 0.14). Which infectious agent is responsible for this condition, considering the patient's age and the clinical and laboratory findings described?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Streptococcus pneu

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient came to the OPD with complaints of fever, sore throat, enlarged lymph nodes, tonsillar swelling, and night sweats. During abdominal examination, a significantly enlarged spleen is noted. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and liver transaminases. A peripheral blood smear displayed lymphocytosis. Further diagnostic testing confirmed the presence of the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) as the causative organism. which of the following conditions should be excluded as not typically associated with EBV?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - E

Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)

  

Classification

Human herpesvirus 4 (HHV-4)

Transmission

- Primarily through saliva, hence "kissing disease"
 

- Can also be transmitted through organ transplantation, blood transfusion, and sexual contact

Diseases Associated

- Infectious mononucleosis (commonly known as mono or glandular fever)
 

- Linked to several types of cancer, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Symptoms of Infectious Mononucleosis

- Fatigue

- Sore throat

- Swollen lymph nodes

- Fever

- Enlarged spleen (splenomegaly)

- Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly)

Latency and Reactivation

EBV can establish lifelong latency in B cells, and reactivation can occur in response to various triggers, such as immunosuppression

Diagnostic Tests

- Monospot test for infectious mononucleosis (detects heterophile antibodies

- Serological tests (IgM and IgG antibodies)

- Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for DNA detection

Treatment

- Supportive care for infectious mononucleosis (rest, fluids, pain relief)

- Antiviral medications in specific cases (e.g., severe complications)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of difficulty in breathing and persistent cough for several days. On examination, he has a black lesion on the upper bridge of the nose. His chest x-ray showed irregular solitary nodules. The physician recommended a tissue biopsy with H&E staining to ascertain the cause. The results of which showed Aseptate hyphae. Which of the following is the characteristic of the biopsy finding?
questions.explanation:
ABSIDIA

Description
  • Absidia is a fungus belonging to the Mucorales group of the zygomycetes class
  • Absidia has aseptate hyphae, which means without cross walls or unbranched hyphae
  • Absidia can cause Zygomycosis, which is a severe fungal infection causing shortness of breath, cough, and fever

Risk Factors

- Immunocompromised individuals (e.g., transplant recipients, leukemia patients)

- Uncontrolled diabetes

- Severe burns or trauma

- Iron overload

- Use of corticosteroids or immunosuppressive drugs

Clinical Presentation

- Can manifest as facial swelling, sinusitis, fever, cough, skin lesions, abdominal pain, and more, depending on the type of mucormycosis

Diagnosis

- Clinical evaluation and imaging (e.g., CT scan or MRI)

- Confirmation through tissue biopsy and fungal culture

Treatment

- Antifungal medications such as amphotericin B and posaconazole

- Surgical debridement of infected tissue

- Management of underlying risk factors

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient arrives at the emergency department with a chief complaint of experiencing shortness of breath and palpitations over the past two hours. The patient is visibly distressed and is sweating profusely. Upon examination, the patient's heart rate is measured at 180 beats per minute, and their systolic blood pressure is only 70 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation reveals no significant abnormalities. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is conducted and indicates narrow QRS complexes. What is the next best step in managing this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Synchronised cardiov

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with chief complaints of watery, non-bloody diarrhea and generalized abdominal pain, which has been progressively worsening over the past 2 days. The patient has no known co-morbidities but was recently admitted for pneumonia, for which he received intravenous antibiotics. On physical examination, the patient exhibits dry mucous membranes, sunken eyes, and abdominal tenderness. His vital signs are as follows: BP- 110/70 mmHg, HR- 88bpm, Temp101°F and RR18bpm. The findings of endoscopy are given below. Which organism is most likely responsible for causing this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

 

Clostridium difficile Infection (CDI)

Transmission

- Fecal-oral route, often in healthcare settings

- Can be spread through contaminated surfaces or hands

Disease Manifestations

- Asymptomatic colonization (carrier state)

- Mild to severe diarrhea

- Pseudomembranous colitis

- Toxic megacolon (rare but life-threatening)

Risk Factors

- Recent antibiotic use (especially broad-spectrum antibiotics

- Healthcare exposure

- Advanced age

- Weakened immune system

- Underlying medical conditions

Diagnostic Tests

- Stool tests for C. difficile toxins (toxin A and toxin B)

- Molecular tests (PCR) for C. difficile DNA

- Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy for severe cases

Treatment

- Discontinuation of the inciting antibiotics (if applicable)

- Antibiotics (e.g., metronidazole, vancomycin) for CDI

- Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) for recurrent CDI

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient presents with a history of fever and fatigue that started 15 days ago followed by headache, weakness, palpitation, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. During the physical examination, her sclerae exhibited sub-icteric discoloration, her skin and conjunctivae appeared pale, and her lips and tongue displayed dryness. questions.correct_answer: B. Wilson and Blair's brilliant-green bismuth sulphite agar medium
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Wilson and Blair's brilliant-green bismuth sulphite agar mediu

 

Enteric Fever

Causative Agent

Salmonella enterica serotype Typhi (S. Typhi)

Transmission

Fecal-oral route, primarily through:

  • Consumption of contaminated food and water
  • Close contact with infected individuals

Incubation Period

Typically 6-30 days after exposure

Clinical Symptoms
  • High fever, often spiking daily and known as "step ladder" fever
  • Abdominal pain, especially in the right lower quadrant
  • Diarrhea or constipation, sometimes with blood and mucus
  • Headache and body aches
  • Weakness and fatigue
  • Rose spots on the abdomen (rash) in some cases

Complications
  • Intestinal perforation, a serious and life-threatening complication
  • Encephalopathy (altered mental state)
  • Hepatitis with elevated liver enzymes
  • Osteomyelitis, especially in children
  • Relapse may occur, necessitating prolonged treatment

Diagnostic Tests
  • Blood culture is the definitive diagnostic test, as it can isolate S. Typhi from the bloodstream
  • Stool culture (less sensitive) to identify the pathogen in feces
  • Serological tests (e.g., Widal test) for antibody detection
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for DNA detection in blood or stool samples

Treatment
  • Antibiotics, such as fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin) or third-generation cephalosporins (ceftriaxone), are effective treatments
  • Supportive care, including fluid and electrolyte replacement

Prevention
  • Ensuring safe drinking water and practicing food hygiene
  • Vaccination is available (Typhoid vaccines) and recommended for travelers to endemic regions and individuals at high risk
  • Travel precautions in endemic areas, such as avoiding street food and using bottled water

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of heart failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with worsening dyspnea and chest pain. On physical examination, decreased breath sounds are noted on the right side of the chest. The clinician suspects pleural effusion. Which specific X-ray view is most appropriate for identifying pleural effusion and assessing its extent in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Decubitus view of the chest
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Decubitus view of the ch

X-ray View Description
Anteroposterior (AP) View Patient faces the X-ray machine, and the X-ray beam passes from the front to the back of the body. Common for chest X-rays.
Posteroanterior (PA) View Patient's back is against the X-ray machine, and the X-ray beam passes from the back to the front of the body. Provides clearer images, especially for lung assessments.
Lateral View Patient stands or lies sideways, and the X-ray beam passes from one side to the other. Provides a side view of structures. Commonly used for spine and extremity imaging.
Oblique View Patient is positioned at an angle to the X-ray machine. Used to visualize structures that may be obscured in standard views, providing a different perspective on the anatomy.
Decubitus View Patient lies down on their side, allowing fluid or air to accumulate against the chest wall, aiding in the diagnosis of pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
Towne's View Special view used for visualizing the base of the skull. The patient's head is tilted slightly forward, and the X-ray beam is directed upward from below the patient's head.
Waters' View Used for facial bone imaging. Patient stands facing the X-ray machine with the forehead and nose pressed against the film. The X-ray beam is directed horizontally.
CT Scan (Computed Tomography) Series of X-ray images taken from different angles to create detailed cross-sectional images. Provides more detailed information than conventional X-rays for internal structures.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with skin lesions and nerve involvement. On examination, there are multiple hypopigmented macules, as well as some erythematous and elevated plaques with sensory loss. The patient also exhibits thickened nerves on palpation. A slit skin smear confirms the presence of acid-fast bacilli. Based on the clinical presentation, which classification of leprosy according to the Ridley-Jopling classification system is most likely to be assigned to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ridley-Jopling classification for leprosy :

Clinical Features

Skin Lesions

Histopathology

Bacteriological Findings

TT (Tuberculoid Tuberculoid)

- Limited skin involvement.

- Sharp demarcation between affected and unaffected skin.

- Localized nerve involvement.

- Few bacilli seen under microscopy.

- Hypopigmented, erythematous plaques.

- Well-defined margins.

- Anesthetic (numb) patches.

- Granulomas with few bacilli.

- Few or no acid-fast bacilli in lesions.

BT (Borderline Tuberculoid)

- More extensive skin involvement.

- Less sharply demarcated borders.

- Mild to moderate nerve involvement.

- Moderate bacilli seen under microscopy.

- Hypopigmented or erythematous patches.

- Less anesthetic involvement.

- Granulomas with more bacilli.

- Scattered acid-fast bacilli.

BB (Borderline Borderline)

- Intermediate form with variable features.

- Borderline lesions, may resemble BT or BB.

- Variable histopathology.

- Variable bacteriological findings.

BL (Borderline Lepromatous)

- More widespread skin involvement.

- Multiple skin lesions.

- Less or more nerve involvement.

- Moderate to numerous bacilli seen under microscopy.

- Lesions may be infiltrated and nodular.

- May have impaired sensation.

- Prominent foamy macrophages.

- Few granulomas.

- Numerous acid-fast bacilli.

LL (Lepromatous Lepromatous)

- Extensive skin involvement.

- Numerous skin lesions.

- More severe nerve involvement.

- Numerous bacilli seen under microscopy.

- Diffuse, infiltrated lesions.

- May have impaired sensation or anesthesia.

- Absence of granulomas.

- Numerous acid-fast bacilli.

I (Indeterminate)

- Early, undefined form.

- Single or few hypopigmented macules.

- Often normal or mild.

- Rarely seen.

questions.text: A 4-year-old pediatric patient presents with complaints of abdominal pain and perianal itching. The attending physician suspects ascariasis as a possible cause of the symptoms and recommends a laboratory test to determine the total parasite rate. The diagram below illustrates the technique used: In which of the following layers are the oocytes of the organisms found?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - S

 

Formol Ether Sedimentation Technique

Purpose

Concentration and detection of parasitic ova and cysts in stool samples

Principle

Separation of parasites and debris from the liquid portion of the stool sample

Reagents Used
  • 10% formalin solution (to fix the sample)
  • Diethyl ether (to concentrate the sample)
  • Distilled water (to suspend the sample)

Procedure
  • Stool sample is mixed with 10% formalin solution.
  • The mixture is strained to remove large debris.
  • Diethyl ether is added and vigorously shaken.
  • The sample is centrifuged, resulting in layers (sediment, ether, and liquid).
  • The sediment is examined under a microscope for parasitic elements.

Advantages
  • Effective in concentrating parasites, making them easier to detect
  • Suitable for a wide range of parasites
  • Relatively simple and cost-effective

Limitations
  • Time-consuming due to the need for centrifugation
  • Potential exposure to formalin and ether, which can be hazardous
  • May not detect all parasites (e.g., some protozoa)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with a 2-month history of moderate epigastric pain and a sensation of fullness accompanied by nausea, decrease in appetite and 8kg weight loss. Additionally, he experienced a dry cough, an itchy rash, and passed bloody stools. Laboratory tests revealed the presence of anemia and neutropenia, while eosinophil levels remained within the normal range. A stool sample was collected and the patient was initiated on albendazole treatment, which subsequently led to an improvement in his condition. What is most likely to be the causative agent ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B – Strong

  Strongyloidiasis
Causative Agent Strongyloides stercoralis (parasitic nematode)
Transmission

- Penetration of larvae through the skin (soil-transmitted)

- Autoinfection (intestinal)
Clinical Symptoms

- Gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, diarrhea)

- Pulmonary symptoms (cough, wheezing)

- Dermatological symptoms (itchy rash)

- Eosinophilia (elevated eosinophil levels in blood)
Chronic Infection - May persist for years or even decades if untreated
Hyperinfection Syndrome

- Occurs in immunocompromised individuals

- Can lead to disseminated strongyloidiasis with severe symptoms and organ involvement
Diagnosis

- Stool examination for larvae (not always sensitive)

- Serological tests (ELISA, Western blot)

- Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for DNA detection
Treatment

- Albendazole or ivermectin for uncomplicated cases

- Prolonged and aggressive treatment for hyperinfection syndrome
Prevention

- Avoidance of contact with contaminated soil

- Appropriate sanitation and hygiene practices

Term

Description

Superfecundation

The fertilization of two or more ova by sperm from separate acts of sexual intercourse within the same menstrual cycle.

Heteropaternal

Twins conceived by two different fathers.

Different fathers

Twins who have different biological fathers due to superfecundation.

Dual paternity

The occurrence of twins having different biological fathers.

Hyperovulation

The release of multiple eggs during a single menstrual cycle, increases the chance of fertilization by different fathers.

Specificity

Ability of test to identify correctly all those who don’t have the disease, that is “true negative”.

Positive predictive value

Probability that subjects with a positive screening test truly have the disease.

Negative predictive value

Probability that subjects with a negative screening test truly don’t have the disease.

a+b

Negative

d (True-negative)

Total

Type Main Features Associated Conditions Monoclonality Rheumatoid Factor (RF) Positivity
Type I
  • Consists of a single monoclonal immunoglobulin (usually IgM).

 Yes Rarely
Type II
  • Contains a mixture of monoclonal and polyclonal immunoglobulins, with the monoclonal component usually being IgM.

 Yes Often

  • Consists of polyclonal immunoglobulins (e.g., IgG and IgM) that form immune complexes at low temperatures.

  • Frequently seen in autoimmune diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

 No Often

questions.text: Congenital cataracts result from specific genetic and metabolic abnormalities, leading to the development of opacities in the eye lens. Mutations in particular genes play a crucial role in the formation of these lens opacities. Among these genetic factors, which gene is most frequently associated with congenital cataracts, especially when related to alpha-crystallin mutations?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - CRYAA

  Congenital cataract
Definition Congenital cataracts are opacities or clouding of the eye's lens that are present at birth.
Incidence Approximately 1 in 2500 live births is affected by congenital cataracts.
Types

1. Nuclear cataract: Opacity at the center of the lens.

2. Cortical cataract: Opacity in the lens cortex (outer layer).

3. Subcapsular cataract: Opacity at the back of the lens, just beneath the lens capsule.

4. Total cataract: Complete lens opacification.
Etiology

- Genetic mutations (autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, X-linked)

- Infections during pregnancy (rubella, toxoplasmosis)

- Metabolic disorders (galactosemia)

- Trauma during childbirth

- Maternal drug use (e.g., corticosteroids)
Pathophysiology 

- Congenital cataracts often result from specific genetic mutations affecting lens development.

- These mutations can disrupt lens fiber cell differentiation, elongation, and compaction, leading to lens opacities.

- Abnormalities in crystallin proteins, especially alpha-crystallin, are frequently associated with congenital cataracts.

- Opacities interfere with the transmission of light to the retina, leading to visual impairment.
Clinical Features

- Clouded or white appearance in the pupil area

- Decreased vision or poor visual response in infants

- Nystagmus  

- Strabismus  

- Amblyopia  

- Refractive errors 
Diagnosis

- Clinical examination

- Slit-lamp examination

- Genetic testing for underlying mutations

- Systemic evaluation for associated conditions
Management

- Surgical removal of the cataract (lens extraction)

- Intraocular lens (IOL) implantation, often in older children

-Correction of refractive errors with glasses or contact lenses

- Amblyopia treatment (patching the better eye)

- Ongoing follow-up for visual development

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the hematology clinic with a history of persistent fatigue, easy bruising, and recurrent infections over the past few months. On examination, he has pallor and petechiae. A complete blood count (CBC) reveals severe pancytopenia with marked dysplasia in all cell lineages, including hypolobated neutrophils and nuclear blebbing in erythroid precursors. The peripheral blood smear also shows abnormal cell morphology. A bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS).Which genetic abnormality is most commonly associated with the development of MDS?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Deletion of chromosome 5q


Myelodysplastic Syndrome
Definition A group of hematological disorders characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis, dysplasia in one or more cell lineages, and an increased risk of progression to acute leukemia.
Epidemiology More common in older adults, with the median age of diagnosis being around 70 years.
Classification MDS is classified into several subtypes based on the extent of dysplasia, the number of cytopenias, and the presence of specific cytogenetic abnormalities. Common subtypes include refractory anemia (RA), refractory cytopenia with multilineage dysplasia (RCMD), and del(5q) syndrome.
Clinical Features
  • Fatigue, weakness, and pallor due to anemia.
  • Easy bruising and bleeding tendencies due to thrombocytopenia.
  • Recurrent infections due to neutropenia.
Diagnosis
  • Complete Blood Count (CBC) with peripheral blood smear.
  • Bone marrow biopsy and aspirate for confirmation, which may show dysplastic changes.
  • Cytogenetic analysis to identify specific genetic abnormalities.
Genetic Abnormalities
  • Deletion of chromosome 5q (del(5q)) is a common genetic abnormality in MDS.
  • Other cytogenetic abnormalities may include trisomy 8 and monosomy 7.
Treatment
  • Supportive care with blood transfusions, growth factors, and antibiotics as needed.
  • Disease-modifying therapies, such as lenalidomide for del(5q) MDS.
  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) for eligible patients, especially those with higher-risk MDS.
Prognosis
  • Variable depending on MDS subtype and risk factors.
  • Risk stratification systems (e.g., IPSS-R) help predict the likelihood of progression to acute leukemia and guide treatment decisions.
Complications
  • Progression to acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a major concern, especially in higher-risk MDS.
  • Infections and bleeding can be life-threatening due to cytopenias.
Patient Education Patients should be educated about the importance of regular follow-up, monitoring for changes in symptoms, and potential treatment options.
Research and Advances Ongoing research explores novel targeted therapies and genetic markers to better understand and manage MDS.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient seeks medical attention, reporting a recent onset of "difficulty in seeing" that has persisted for the past three days. He notes a change in his vision following an incident of eye trauma. The patient has a history of heavy smoking and alcohol consumption. On examination, the patient's vital signs are stable, except for mild hypertension with a blood pressure reading of 154/87 mmHg. The patient demonstrates full extraocular motility in both eyes and exhibits normal red reflexes. The image below depicts the pupillary light reflex of this patient: Which of the following options is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Robert Marcus Gunn pu

Term Robert Marcus Gunn Pupil (RAPD)
Definition A distinctive pupillary abnormality characterized by the dilation of the affected pupil instead of the usual constriction when exposed to light. This response indicates a dysfunction in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex.
Etiology Typically arises from various underlying conditions affecting the optic nerve or severe retinal diseases. Common causes include optic neuritis, optic nerve compression, or severe retinal detachment.
Clinical Presentation - When light is directed into the affected eye, the pupil dilates or shows minimal constriction instead of the normal constriction.
  - In contrast, the unaffected eye typically exhibits a normal pupillary response to light.
  - RAPD is often identified through a clinical test called the swinging flashlight test (Marcus Gunn test), where a flashlight is alternated between the two eyes.
Testing - Diagnosis and assessment involve the swinging flashlight test to reveal the presence and quantify the severity of RAPD.
  - Comprehensive examination of visual acuity, funduscopy (evaluation of the optic nerve and retina), and other diagnostic tests to determine the underlying cause.
Diagnostic Significance RAPD is a clinically significant sign indicative of unilateral optic nerve or severe retinal pathology. It's a vital clue for further investigation.
Management - The primary approach is to identify and address the underlying cause of RAPD. Treatment varies based on the specific condition, such as corticosteroids for optic neuritis or surgical interventions for retinal disorders.
  - Regular monitoring and follow-up are crucial to assess any changes in the pupillary response and ensure appropriate management.

questions.text: In a 25-year-old patient with symptoms of sore throat, cough, hoarseness, and red eyes, a doctor diagnoses pharyngitis caused by a Streptococcus species. What property is associated with the C-carbohydrate of the Streptococcus ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - L

 

Lancefield Classification

Definition

A classification system for beta-hemolytic streptococci based on antigenic properties of their cell wall carbohydrates.

Named After

Dr. Rebecca Craighill Lancefield, who developed the system in the 1930s.

Groups Included

Multiple groups, including but not limited to:
 

- Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes)
 

- Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae)
 

- Group C Streptococcus (e.g., Streptococcus equi in animals)
 

- Group D Streptococcus (e.g., Enterococcus faecalis)

Method of Identification

- Lancefield grouping can be determined through serological testing, typically using specific antisera.
 

- Detection of specific surface carbohydrates helps classify beta-hemolytic streptococci into different Lancefield groups.

Clinical Significance

- Identifying the Lancefield group of streptococci is important in clinical microbiology and epidemiology. It helps guide treatment and diagnosis of streptococcal infections.

Disease Associations

- Different Lancefield groups are associated with various diseases. For example, Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) is known for causing strep throat and skin infections. Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is a common cause of neonatal sepsis.

Treatment Considerations

- Knowing the Lancefield group of the infecting streptococcus can help determine the appropriate antibiotics for treatment, as susceptibility profiles may vary between groups.

Importance in Streptococcal Typing

- Lancefield grouping is one aspect of typing beta-hemolytic streptococci. It is used alongside other methods, such as molecular typing and virulence factor analysis, for epidemiological studies

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath and chest pain for the past hour. She had a hysterectomy for heavy menstrual bleeding two months ago but has no other comorbid. A CT pulmonary angiogram reveals a pulmonary embolism (PE) for which she’s started on heparin and tissue plasminogen activator. Five days after treatment, she develops painful clots in both legs. Her complete blood count is as follows: White blood cells: 8,000/mm 3, Haemoglobin: 11.2 g/dL, Platelet count: 38,000/mm 3 . Which treatments should be started to prevent further clot formation and bleeding?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue heparin therapy at the current dose.

options.label: B
options.text: Start warfarin therapy with overlapping heparin.

questions.correct_answer: B. Start warfarin therapy with overlapping heparin.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Start warfarin therapy with overlapping h

Aspect

Treatment

Prevention

Immediate Management
  • Discontinue all forms of heparin
  • Initiate non-heparin anticoagulation, e.g., direct thrombin inhibitors (e.g., argatroban, bivalirudin) or danaparoid
  • Begin treatment even if thrombosis is not clinically evident
  • Consider alternatives to heparin
  • Use alternative anticoagulants (e.g., direct oral anticoagulants, fondaparinux)
  • Implement clinical scoring systems to assess HIT risk (e.g., 4T score)

Monitoring
  • Frequent platelet count monitoring
  • Adjust anticoagulation based on platelet count trends and clinical assessment

 

Duration of Treatment
  • Continue non-heparin anticoagulation for at least until platelet count has stabilized and HIT antibodies have disappeared
  • Continue non-heparin anticoagulation for the duration of thrombosis risk or until HIT antibodies have disappeared

Thrombosis Management
  • For established thrombosis, administer therapeutic doses of anticoagulants based on the type and location of thrombosis (e.g., deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism)
  

Prevention of HIT
  • Use alternative anticoagulants in high-risk patients (e.g., surgical patients, medical ICU)
  • Avoid heparin exposure in low-risk patients (e.g., prophylactic use)
  • Avoid unnecessary heparin exposure
  • Use low-dose heparin flushes in central venous catheters (if needed)
  • Consider alternative methods of anticoagulation for prophylaxis

Patient Education
  • Inform patients about the risks and symptoms of HIT
  • Encourage reporting of any unusual symptoms, such as new thrombosis or skin necrosis
  • Educate healthcare providers about
  • HIT risk factors and prevention strategies

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy visits a physician, reporting symptoms of muscle stiffness, pain, jaw cramping, difficulty swallowing, and jerky muscle movements that have been occurring for the past eight days. Additionally, the boy has experienced intermittent fever. Upon analyzing a sample and conducting staining, microscopy reveals the presence of spores with a distinctive "drumstick" appearance. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the pathogen responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Inhibition of GABA

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with swelling in his lower extremities and face. He reports that the swelling has been progressively increasing over the past month, and he has also noticed foamy urine. On examination, he appears edematous, with marked bilateral pitting edema. His blood pressure is within the normal range. Laboratory investigations reveal hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and significant proteinuria. A 24-hour urine protein collection confirms proteinuria exceeding 3.5 grams per day. There are no other significant medical conditions in his history. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Nephrotic Syndrome due to Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

questions.correct_answer: A. Nephrotic Syndrome due to Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Nephrotic Syndrome due to Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

Nephrotic Syndrome due to Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
Definition Nephrotic Syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterized by significant proteinuria (>3.5 grams/day), hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia. FSGS is one of the potential underlying renal diseases that can cause Nephrotic Syndrome.
Epidemiology FSGS is a primary glomerular disorder that can affect both children and adults. It is more common in certain high-risk populations, including African Americans.
Pathophysiology FSGS is characterized by scarring (sclerosis) in a subset of glomeruli (the filtering units of the kidneys). This results in altered glomerular permeability, allowing proteins to leak into the urine.
Clinical Features
  • Significant proteinuria (>3.5 grams/day).
  • Hypoalbuminemia, leading to generalized edema.
  • Hyperlipidemia, including elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels.
  • Foamy or frothy urine due to proteinuria.
Diagnosis
  • Urinalysis revealing massive proteinuria.
  • Serum albumin levels below normal (hypoalbuminemia).
  • Lipid profile showing elevated cholesterol and triglycerides.
  • Renal biopsy to confirm FSGS as the underlying cause of Nephrotic Syndrome.
Treatment
  • Immunosuppressive therapy with corticosteroids and other agents may be considered.
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) for blood pressure control and reducing proteinuria.
  • Dietary modifications to manage hyperlipidemia.
  • Diuretics for edema control.
  • In some cases, kidney transplant if conservative treatments are ineffective.
Prognosis Prognosis varies depending on the response to treatment. Some cases of FSGS may progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD), necessitating renal replacement therapy.
Complications
  • Increased risk of thrombosis due to loss of anticoagulant proteins.
  • Malnutrition and muscle wasting due to hypoalbuminemia.
  • Infection risk due to immunosuppressive therapy.
  • Progression to ESRD may require dialysis or kidney transplantation.
Research and Advances Ongoing research focuses on understanding the underlying mechanisms of FSGS and developing targeted therapies to improve outcomes for affected individuals.
